Relatedly, maintenance of good health through the utilization of proper healthcare resources can be quite costly and therefore unaffordable to certain populations. According to the [[Healthy People program|Healthy People 2030]], people with steady employment are less likely to live in poverty and more likely to be healthy, however, many people struggle with finding and keeping a job.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Economic Stability – Healthy People 2030 |url=https://health.gov/healthypeople/objectives-and-data/browse-objectives/economic-stability#cit1 |access-date=2023-04-19 |website=health.gov}}</ref> Social needs, environmental factors and barriers to accessing health care that are unaddressed could lead to worse health outcomes for people with lower incomes.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Thompson |first1=Tess |last2=McQueen |first2=Amy |last3=Kreuter |first3=Matthew |date=January 17, 2019 |title=Social Needs and Health-Related Outcomes Among Medicaid Beneficiaries |url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1090198118822724 |journal=Health Education & Behavior |volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=436–444 |doi=10.1177/1090198118822724 |pmid=30654655 |s2cid=58612659 |access-date=April 21, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Phelan |first1=Jo C. |last2=Link |first2=Bruce G. |last3=Tehranifar |first3=Parisa |date=March 2010 |title=Social Conditions as Fundamental Causes of Health Inequalities: Theory, Evidence, and Policy Implications |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0022146510383498 |journal=Journal of Health and Social Behavior |language=en |volume=51 |issue=1_suppl |pages=S28–S40 |doi=10.1177/0022146510383498 |issn=0022-1465 |pmid=20943581 |s2cid=9729554}}</ref> Additionally, residents of impoverished communities are at increased risk for [[mental illness]], [[chronic disease]], [[Mortality rate|higher mortality]], and [[Life expectancy|lower life expectancy]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Poverty – Healthy People 2030 |url=https://health.gov/healthypeople/priority-areas/social-determinants-health/literature-summaries/poverty#cit10 |access-date=2023-04-21 |website=health.gov |language=en}}</ref>
Housing is another critical aspect of economics as a social determinant of health. In a 2020 housing study in which millions of court records on renter [[Eviction in the United States|evictions]] were analyzed, the evidence on racial and gender demographics were dramatic.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Hepburn |first1=Peter |last2=Louis |first2=Renee |last3=Desmond |first3=Matthew |date=December 16, 202 |title=Racial and Gender Disparities among Evicted Americans |url=https://sociologicalscience.com/articles-v7-27-649/ |access-date=2023-12-07 |website=sociologicalscience.com |page=649}}</ref> Black and Latino tenants experienced significantly higher eviction rates than their white counterparts. And housing instability plays a critical role in health outcomes: when families have to spend a disproportionately high percentage of income (30% or more) on housing, there are insufficient funds remaining for essentials such as healthy foods, consistent health care, and medications.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Reduce the proportion of families that spend more than 30 percent of income on housing — SDOH‑04 - Healthy People 2030 {{!}} health.gov |url=https://health.gov/healthypeople/objectives-and-data/browse-objectives/housing-and-homes/reduce-proportion-families-spend-more-30-percent-income-housing-sdoh-04 |access-date=2023-12-07 |website=health.gov}}</ref> Racial disparities in eviction rates correspond to negative health outcomes, including depression.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Hepburn |first1=Peter |last2=Louis |first2=Renee |last3=Desmond |first3=Matthew |date=2020 |title=Racial and Gender Disparities among Evicted Americans |url=https://sociologicalscience.com/articles-v7-27-649/ |journal=Sociological Science |volume=7 |pages=659 |doi=10.15195/v7.a27|doi-access=free }}</ref>
Food security—meaning consistent availability and affordability of food that promotes well-being and prevents disease—is another important social determinant of health linked to economics.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Food and Nutrition Security |url=https://www.usda.gov/nutrition-security |access-date=2023-12-07 |website=www.usda.gov |language=en}}</ref> Food insecurity increases in neighborhoods where access to healthy food is limited because of travel distance to supermarkets and lack of transportation.<ref name=":03">{{Cite web |title=Food Insecurity - Healthy People 2030 {{!}} health.gov |url=https://health.gov/healthypeople/priority-areas/social-determinants-health/literature-summaries/food-insecurity |access-date=2023-12-07 |website=health.gov |language=en}}</ref> Families living in poverty struggle with consistent access to sufficient healthy food, and suffer negative health outcomes as a result; food insecurity has been demonstrated to correlate with many health issues, including [[Chronic condition|chronic disease]] and obesity.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Gregory |first1=Christian A. |last2=Coleman-Jensen |first2=Alisha |date=July 2017 |title=Food Insecurity, Chronic Disease, and Health Among Working-Age Adults |url= |journal=ERR |publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture, Economic Research Service |volume=235 |doi= |issn=}}</ref>
As one's job or career is a primary conduit for both financial and social capital, work is an important, yet under represented, factor in health inequities research and prevention efforts.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal |last1=Ahonen |first1=Emily Quinn |last2=Fujishiro |first2=Kaori |last3=Cunningham |first3=Thomas |last4=Flynn |first4=Michael |date=2018 |title=Work as an Inclusive Part of Population Health Inequities Research and Prevention |journal=American Journal of Public Health |language=en |volume=108 |issue=3 |pages=306–311 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2017.304214 |issn=0090-0036 |pmc=5803801 |pmid=29345994}}</ref> There are many ways that a job can affect one's health, such as the job's physical demands, exposure to hazards, mechanisms of employment, compensation and benefits, and availability of health and safety programs. In addition, those who are in steady jobs are less likely to face poverty and its implications and more likely to have access to health care.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Shi |first1=L. |last2=Starfield |first2=B. |last3=Kennedy |first3=B. |last4=Kawachi |first4=I. |date=1999 |title=Income inequality, primary care, and health indicators |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10229252 |journal=The Journal of Family Practice |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=275–284 |issn=0094-3509 |pmid=10229252}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Finkel |first=Adam M. |date=2018 |title=A Healthy Public Cannot Abide Unhealthy And Unsafe Workplaces |journal=American Journal of Public Health |language=en |volume=108 |issue=3 |pages=312–313 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2017.304282 |issn=0090-0036 |pmc=5803826 |pmid=29412707}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Fujishiro |first1=Kaori |last2=Ahonen |first2=Emily Q. |last3=Gimeno Ruiz de Porras |first3=David |last4=Chen |first4=I.-Chen |last5=Benavides |first5=Fernando G. |date=2021 |title=Sociopolitical values and social institutions: Studying work and health equity through the lens of political economy |journal=SSM – Population Health |volume=14 |pages=100787 |doi=10.1016/j.ssmph.2021.100787 |issn=2352-8273 |pmc=8056461 |pmid=33898729}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Silver |first1=Sharon R. |last2=Li |first2=Jia |last3=Quay |first3=Brian |date=2022 |title=Employment status, unemployment duration, and health-related metrics among US adults of prime working age: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, 2018–2019 |journal=American Journal of Industrial Medicine |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=59–71 |doi=10.1002/ajim.23308 |issn=1097-0274 |pmc=8678322 |pmid=34748231}}</ref>
===Education=== {{Research paper|date=September 2024}} Education plays an especially influential part in the lives of the impoverished. Education determines other factors of livelihood like occupation and income that determines income, which determines health outcomes.<ref name=edu /> Education is a major social determinant of health, with educational attainment related to improved health outcomes, due to its effect on income, employment, and living conditions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ross | first1 = Catherine E. | last2 = Wu | first2 = Chia-ling | name-list-style = vanc | title = The Links Between Education and Health | journal = American Sociological Review | date = October 1995 | volume = 60 | issue = 5 | pages = 719 | doi = 10.2307/2096319 | jstor = 2096319 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.462.815 }}</ref><ref name = "Cutler_2006">{{cite book | chapter = Education and Health: Evaluating Theories and Evidence | first1 = David M. | last1 = Cutler | first2 = Adriana | last2 = Lleras-Muney | veditors = House J, Schoeni R, Kaplan G, Pollack H | title = Making Americans Healthier: Social and Economic Policy as Health Policy | location = New York | publisher = Russell Sage Foundation | date = July 2006 | doi = 10.3386/w12352 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.497.5604 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first1 = David E. | last1 = Bloom | first2 = David | last2 = Canning | first3 = Gunther | last3 = Fink | name-list-style = vanc | year = 2014 | title = Disease and Development Revisited | journal = Journal of Political Economy | volume = 122 | issue = 6 | pages = 1355–1366 | doi = 10.1086/677189 | hdl = 10419/80633 | s2cid = 14325019 | url = https://econpapers.repec.org/RePEc:iza:izadps:dp7391 | hdl-access = free }}</ref><ref name=WHO /> Social resources, such as education, determine life expectancy and infant mortality, which measures health.<ref name=HHS>{{cite report | title = Health, United States 2010 | publisher = U.S. Department of Health and Human Services: Center for Disease Control and Prevention. National Center for Health Statistics | date = 2010 | location = Hyattsville, MD. | url = https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/hus/hus10.pdf }}</ref> Education has a lasting, continuous, and increasing effect on health.<ref name=WHO /> Education is a special determinant of health because it enables people toward self-direction, which leads them to seek goals such as health.<ref name=WHO /> Education helps the impoverished develop usable skills, abilities, and resources that help individuals reach goals, including bettering health.<ref name=edu /> Parent's educational level is also important to health, which influences the health of children and the future population. Parent's education level also determines child health, survival, and their educational attainment (Caldwell, 1986; Cleland & Van Ginneken, 1988).<ref name=WHO /> "Children born to more educated mothers are less likely to die in infancy and more likely to have higher birth weights and be immunized.<ref name=WDR12 /> Studies in the United States suggest maternal education results in higher parity, greater use of prenatal care, and lower smoking rates, which positively affects child health.<ref name=WDR12 /> An increase in child schooling in Taiwan during the educational reform of 1968 reduced the infant morality rate by 11%, saving 1 infant per 1000 births.<ref name=WDR12 />
=== Occupation === {{Research paper|date=September 2024}} Impoverished workers are more likely to hold part-time jobs, move in and out of work, be migrant workers, or experience stress associated with being unemployed and searching unsuccessfully for unemployment, which all in turn affects health outcomes.<ref name=WHO /> According to the [[World Health Organization]], employment and working conditions greatly affect health equity (Kivimaki et al., 2003).<ref name=WHO /> This occurs because poor employment conditions exposes individuals to health hazards, which are more likely for low-status jobs.<ref name=WHO /> Evidence confirms that high job demand, low control, and low rewards for effort in these low status jobs are risk factors for mental and physical health problems, such as a 50% excess risk of heart disease (Stansfeld & Candy, 2006).<ref name=WHO /> The growing power of massive, conglomerate global corporations and institutions to set labor policy and standards agendas has disempowered workers, unions, and the job-seeking by subjecting these individuals to health-damaging working conditions. (EMCONET, 2007).<ref name=WHO /> In high- income countries, there has been a growth in job insecurity and precarious employment arrangements (such as informal work, temporary work, part-time work, and piecework), job losses, and a weakening of regulatory protections. Informal work can threaten health through its precarious job instability, lack of regulation to protect working conditions and occupational health and safety.<ref name=WHO /> Evidence from the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] suggests mortality is greater among temporary workers than permanent workers. (Kivimaki et al., 2003).<ref name=WHO /> Since most of the global workforce operates under the informal economy, particularly low- and middle-income countries,<ref name=WHO /> impoverished populations are greatly affected by these factors.
=== Migration status === Migrants have a variety of physical and mental health needs, shaped by their background, the host country's entry and integration policies, and their living and working conditions.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=Refugee and migrant health |url=https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/refugee-and-migrant-health |access-date=2022-12-02 |website=www.who.int |language=en}}</ref> Refugees and migrants remain among the most vulnerable members of society and may be faced with inadequate or restricted access to health services.<ref name=":1" /> Xenophobia, discrimination, and working conditions may further affect their mental health disproportionally.<ref name=":1" /> Comparison of a poor but mainly non-migrant population in rural Uganda with disadvantaged migrant population in urban South-Africa and urban Sweden found lower self-reported frequency of physical activity and lower social support and self-efficacy in the urban migrant samples.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=De Man |first1=Jeroen |last2=Kasujja |first2=Francis Xavier |last3=Delobelle |first3=Peter |last4=Annerstedt |first4=Kristi Sidney |last5=Alvesson |first5=Helle Mölsted |last6=Absetz |first6=Pilvikki |last7=Wouters |first7=Edwin |last8=Daivadanam |first8=Meena |last9=Guwatudde |first9=David |last10=Puoane |first10=Thandi |last11=Remmen |first11=Roy |last12=Tabana |first12=Hanani |last13=Van Olmen |first13=Josefien |date=December 2022 |title=Motivational determinants of physical activity in disadvantaged populations with (pre)diabetes: a cross-cultural comparison |journal=BMC Public Health |language=en |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=164 |doi=10.1186/s12889-022-12539-9 |issn=1471-2458 |pmc=8787976 |pmid=35073882 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
==Socioeconomic and political context==
===Location===
====Nation-state/geographical region==== {{Research paper|date=September 2024}} Which particular nation an impoverished person lives in deeply affects health outcomes. This can be attributed to governmental, environmental, geographical, and cultural factors. Using life expectancy as a measure of health indicates a difference between countries in likeliness of living to a certain age. Where people are born dramatically impacts their life chances. High-income countries like [[Japan]] or [[Sweden]] have a life expectancy of 80 years, [[Brazil]]-72, [[India]]-63.<ref name=HIV /> The [[World Health Organization|WHO]] cites that for rich countries, only 56 (Iceland) to 107 (US) of 1000 adults between 15 and 60 years old will die each year, while Western and Central African countries have adult mortality rates exceeding 300 and 400 of every 1000. The rates are even higher in African nations in the AIDS epidemic, such as [[Zimbabwe]] where 772 of 1000 adults die each year (WHO 2010).<ref name=WDR12 /> Also, the type of health condition varies by countries for populations in poverty. Over 80% of [[cardiovascular disease]] deaths, that totaled 17.5 million people globally in 2005, occur in low- and middle-income countries.<ref name=WHO /> According to the [[World Health Organization|WHO]],13500 people die from smoking every day, and soon it will become the leading cause of death in developing countries, just as in high income countries. (Mathers & Loncar, 2005).<ref name=WHO />
Infant and [[maternal mortality]] also reveals disparity in health between nations. There exist great inequalities in infant death rates within and between countries, ranging from 20/10000 births in Columbia to 120/10000 in Mozambique.<ref name=WHO/> In 1985, The World Health Organization estimated that maternal mortality rates were 150 times higher in developing countries than developed nations.<ref name=below>{{cite journal | last = Farmer | first = Paul | name-list-style = vanc | year = 1996 | title = On Suffering and Structural Violence: A View from Below | journal = Social Suffering | volume = 125 | issue = 1 | pages = 261–283 | jstor = 20027362 }}</ref>
====Urban or rural location====
=====Urban===== {{Research paper|date=September 2024}} The location where people live affects their health and life outcomes,<ref name=WHO /> which means impoverished people's health outcomes are especially determined by whether they live in a [[metropolitan area]] or rural area.<ref name=WHO /> In the 19th and 20th century, slums developed in cities and the ensuing crowding, poor sanitation, and inadequate dwellings brought infectious disease and illnesses, causing public health concerns.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Krieger J, Higgins DL | title = Housing and health: time again for public health action | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 92 | issue = 5 | pages = 758–68 | date = May 2002 | pmid = 11988443 | pmc = 1447157 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.92.5.758 }}</ref> With the prevalence of inner city [[ghettos]] and [[slums]] around the globe in cities, with approximately 1 billion people living in slums globally,<ref name=WHO /> living situation is an especially strong determinant of health in poverty. Urban areas present health risks through poor living conditions, limited food resources, traffic accidents, and [[pollution]].<ref name=WHO/> Urbanization is immensely altering public health problems, particularly for the poor, by directing it towards non-communicable diseases, accidental and violent injuries, and death and health impacts from ecological disaster. (Capbell & Campbell, 2007;{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}} Yusuf et al., 2001).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> Daily living conditions enormously impact health equity too.<ref name=WHO /> Equity in living conditions, such as access to quality housing and clean water and hygiene, have been greatly degraded in urban areas by increasing [[car dependence]], land use for roads, inconvenience of non-car transportation, air quality, greenhouse gas emissions, and lack of physical activity (NHF, 2007).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> The challenges of urban areas, such as high population density, crowding, unsuitable living conditions, and little social support, provide a special challenge to disabled people and populations in low and middle income countries (Frumkin et al., 2004).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> * [[Obesity]]: Obesity is a paramount problem, especially among the poor and socially disadvantaged, in cities worldwide, according to the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] (Hawkes et al., 2007;{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}} Friel, Chopra & Satcher, 2007).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> The increased amount of obesity can be contributed to the [[nutrition transition]] that describes how people are now increasingly turning to high-fat, sugar, and salt food sources because of their availability and price.<ref name=WHO /> This food transition has fueled the obesity epidemic. This nutrition transition tends to start in cities because of "greater availability, accessibility, and acceptability of bulk purchases, convenience foods, and '[[supersized]]' portions" (Dixon et al., 2007).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> Physical activity and exercise is strongly determined by the design of cities, including density of homes, heterogeneous land uses, the extent to which streets and sidewalks connect, the [[walkability]], and the provision of and access to local public accommodations and parks for recreation and play.<ref name=WHO /> These factors, along with increasing reliance on cars, results in the shift of the population toward physical inactivity, which damages health (Friel, Chopra & Satcher, 2007).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> * Crime: Violence and crime are major urban health challenges. Worldwide, 90% of the 1.6 million annual violent deaths occur in low and middle income counties (WHO, 2002).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> A large number of deaths and injuries occur because of crime, which affects health.<ref name=WHO /> * Traffic: Individuals in ghettos and urban areas are the most affected by traffic injuries and vehicle-created air pollution, which causes 800,000 annual deaths due to air pollution, and 1.2 million from traffic accidents. (Roberts & Meddings, 2007;{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}} Prüss- Üstün & Corvalán, 2006).{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}}<ref name=WHO /> This results in greater health risks, like death,<ref name=WHO /> for impoverished populations in cities. * Mental illness: Living in a ghetto increases the likelihood of developing a mental illness, especially in children. People in this environment are less likely to receive effective mental health services. Children exposed to ongoing poverty, present in a ghetto, present a high level of depression, anxiety, social withdrawal, peer conflict and aggression.<ref>(McLeod & Shanahan, 1997)</ref>{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}} Mental health symptoms are increased in the ghetto due to exposure to community crime, gang induced violence, neighborhood drug infestations, and substandard housing conditions.<ref>(González 2005)</ref>{{full citation needed|date=July 2022}} * Other: In the United States, HIV is more prevalent in cities along the east coast, with prevalence among African-American women in cities 5 to 15 times higher than for women in all areas of that state.<ref name=HIV /> "Inner-city women are the most likely of all in the United States to birth dead or extremely sick babies, partially because the massive erosion of prenatal care availability in their area.<ref name=HIV /> Slums, made up exclusively of extremely poor populations, provide a particularly strong threat for poor health. Child mortality in the slums of Nairobi, which 60% of the population inhabits, is 2.5 times greater than in other areas of the city.<ref name=WHO /> In the slums of Manila, 39% of children have TB, which is twice the national average.<ref name=WHO /> The term 'housing instability' describes a condition in which people have been or will be homeless in the future. People facing such instability have poorer health care access and more acute health problems than the rest of the population.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Reid KW, Vittinghoff E, Kushel MB | title = Association between the level of housing instability, economic standing and health care access: a meta-regression | journal = Journal of Health Care for the Poor and Underserved | volume = 19 | issue = 4 | pages = 1212–28 | date = November 2008 | pmid = 19029747 | doi = 10.1353/hpu.0.0068 | s2cid = 35633985 }}</ref> A city populations grew and rents rose, those receiving Section 9 housing vouchers could no longer afford the rising rents and were forced to move away.<ref>{{Cite journal| vauthors = Varady DP, Walker CC |date=January 2003|title=Using housing vouchers to move to the suburbs: How do families fare? |journal=Housing Policy Debate|language=en|volume=14|issue=3|pages=347–382|doi=10.1080/10511482.2003.9521480 |s2cid=154468722}}</ref>
=====Rural===== Living in a rural community, whether in the United States, or around the globe, reduces access to medical services, [[health insurance]], and changes health culture.<ref name=WHO /><ref name=child /><ref name=rural /> Differentials exist between rural and urban communities, and some health disadvantages exist for impoverished rural residents. Since health of a population increases in geographical locations that have a higher prevalence of primary care physicians,<ref name=WHO /> rural areas face worse health. According to certain studies, measures of health and well-being indicate that rural populations have worse health outcomes.<ref name=rural /> Rural residents have a greater rate of premature mortality (less than age 75 at death) than urban residents.<ref name=rural /> According to certain studies in the United States, the death rate of individuals age 1–24 years was 31% higher than those in urban counties.<ref name=rural /> The death rate of adults 25 to 64 years old was 32% higher among rural residents than those of suburban counties and of urban counties.<ref name=rural /> These higher death rates were contributed to unintentional injuries, suicide, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.<ref name=rural /> In 1997 in the United States, 18% of adults in rural areas had chronic health conditions, compared to only 13% of suburban adults.<ref name=rural /> The National Health Interview Survey indicated that in 1998, 16% of rural adults reported poor health.<ref name=rural /> Poor rural residents have only 21% Medicaid coverage, while poor urban populations report 30% coverage.<ref name=rural /> Demographic and socioeconomic factors vary between rural and urban areas, which contributes to some health disparities.<ref name=rural>{{cite journal | first1 = Mark S. | last1 = Eberhardt | first2 = Elsie R. | last2 = Pamuk | name-list-style = vanc | title = he Importance of Place of Residence: Examining Health in Rural and Nonrural Areas | journal = American Journal of Public Health | date = October 2004 | volume = 94 | issue = 10 | pages = 1682–1686 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.94.10.1682 | pmid = 15451731 | pmc = 1448515 }}</ref> For extremely poor rural communities, variables in the community, like ecological setting, including climate, soil, rainfall, temperature, altitude, and [[seasonality]] greatly impact health.<ref name=child /> "In rural subsistence societies, these variables can have strong influence on child survival by affecting the quantity and variety of food crops produced, the availability and quality of water, vector-borne [[disease transmission]]"<ref name=child />
===Governance/policy=== Type and structure of governments and their social and economic policy more deeply affects the health of the impoverished than other populations.<ref name=WHO /> Every component of government- from finance, education, housing, employment, transportation, and [[health policy]]- affects population health and health equity.<ref name=WHO /> Life expectancy variation between countries can be partially attributed to the type of political regime, whether that be [[fascist]], [[communist]], [[conservative]], or [[social-democratic]].<ref name=dia /> It is suggested by WHO that those who are the most vulnerable and affected by policy changes that influence their quality of health should have a direct hand in the construction and adoption of these same policies. This power in contribution would have a positive impact on their health outcomes, due to their ability to participate autonomously in policies that influence their health'''.'''<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Blas|first1=Erik|last2=Gilson|first2=Lucy|last3=Kelly|first3=Michael P.|last4=Labonté|first4=Ronald|last5=Lapitan|first5=Jostacio|last6=Muntaner|first6=Carles|last7=Östlin|first7=Piroska|last8=Popay|first8=Jennie|last9=Sadana|first9=Ritu|last10=Sen|first10=Gita|last11=Schrecker|first11=Ted|date=2008-11-08|title=Addressing social determinants of health inequities: what can the state and civil society do?|url=https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(08)61693-1/abstract|journal=The Lancet|language=en|volume=372|issue=9650|pages=1684–1689|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(08)61693-1|issn=0140-6736|pmid=18994667|hdl=1828/7838|s2cid=25782484|hdl-access=free}}</ref> However, changing the status of government regime does not always end the type of policies in place, as seen in South Africa. The end of South Africa's apartheid regime has still not dismantled the structures of inequality and oppression, which has led the persistent social inequality to perpetuate the spread of HIV, diminishing population health.<ref name=path /> Also, the political economy, encompassing production organization, physical [[infrastructure]], and political institutions [9] play a large role in determining health inequalities.<ref name=child />
===Social service and healthcare availability===
[[File:CDC healthcare source adults.png|600px|right|alt=health care source|No usual source of healthcare due to weak social safety net]]
The social environment that impoverished people dwell in is often a precursor to the quality of their health outcomes. Without equitable access to basic social needs, it is difficult to have a quality standard of health while under a significant financial burden. The Commission of Social Determinants of Health, created in 2015 by the World Health Organization, was a pioneer in the push for more focus on "creating better social conditions for health, particularly among the most vulnerable people".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://courses.arcade-project.org/pluginfile.php/275/mod_resource/content/2/History%20of%20the%20SDH%20-%201.pdf|title=History of the Social Determinants of Health|website=ARCADE Project}}</ref> These basic social needs that influence social environment include food security, housing, education, transportation, healthcare access and more factors that can affect health. Social services and social service programs, which provide support in access to basic social needs, are made critical in the improvement in health conditions of the impoverished. Impoverished people depend on healthcare and other social services to be provided in the [[social safety net]], therefore availability greatly determines health outcomes. Since low living standards greatly influence health inequity, generous social protection systems result in greater population health, with lower mortality rates, especially in disadvantaged populations.<ref name=HIV /> A successful example of such social service program is the Senior Companion program, an extension of the United States federal program [[Senior Corps]]. The program provides assistance for adults who have physical and mental disadvantages.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Butler SS, Eckart D | title = Civic engagement among older adults in a rural community: A case study of the senior companion program. | journal = Journal of Community Practice | date = October 2007 | volume = 15 | issue = 3 | pages = 77–98 | doi = 10.1300/J125v15n03_05 | s2cid = 141702515 }}</ref> It pairs up senior volunteers with patients who come from low-income background to help them increase their social capability, ability to live independently and more accessibility to healthcare. A mixed-method study explores that the program does target various social determinants of health and have positive effects on enrolled elders' health status (although less positive correlation long-term).<ref name="pmid16901877">{{cite journal | vauthors = Butler SS | title = Evaluating the Senior Companion Program: a mixed-method approach | journal = Journal of Gerontological Social Work | volume = 47 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 45–70 | date = 2006 | pmid = 16901877 | doi = 10.1300/J083v47n01_05 | s2cid = 22094694 }}</ref> It concludes that the program does have enthusiastic impacts on clients and volunteers' overall wellness.<ref name="Rabiner_2004">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rabiner DJ, Scheffler S, Koetse E, Palermo J, Ponzi E, Burt S, Hampton L | title = The Impact of the Senior Companion Program on Quality of Life Outcomes for Frail Older Adults and Their Families | journal = Home Health Care Services Quarterly | volume = 22 | issue = 4 | pages = 1–26 | date = February 2004 | pmid = 29016256 | doi = 10.1300/J027v22n04_01 | s2cid = 6168883 }}</ref> The result is homogeneous with conclusions from other studies, with emerging themes include: companionship, reduced depression, access to healthcare, isolation, and increased social network.<ref name="Rabiner_2004" /> Another example of a utilized social service program in Northern California is the UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital Oakland Find Program. This program employs a method of addressing the social determinants of health, liaison work, contextualized by their predominantly impoverished patient population. This liaison work involves caseworkers in the clinic connecting patients to basic social needs resources. Similar positive results have been found, suggesting that this liaison work is effective in bettering the health status of those in marginalized positions of society.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.kff.org|title=Beyond Health Care: The Role of Social Determinants in Promoting Health and Health Equity|last=Artiga|first=Samantha|website=Kaiser Family Foundation}}</ref>
Nations that have more generous social protection systems have better population health (Lundberg et al., 2007).<ref name="WHO" /> More generous family policies correlate with lower infant mortality.<ref name="WHO" /> Nations that offered higher coverage and reimbursement for pensions and sickness, unemployment, and employment accident insurance have a higher LEB (Lundberg et al., 2007), as well as countries with more liberal pensions have less senior mortality. (Lundberg et al., 2007)<ref name="WHO" />
====Access to Healthcare==== The health care system represents a social determinant of health as well as it influences other determining factors. People's access to health care, their experiences there, and the benefits they gain are closely related to other social determinants of health like income, gender, education, ethnicity, occupation, and more.<ref name=WHO /> For poor people, systematic barriers in the social structure are formidable, especially financing.<ref name=HIV /> Medicaid and maternity coverage structures have complex and time-consuming registration processes, along with long waits and unsure eligibility.<ref name=HIV /> A study of the Emergency Department found that the majority of patients presenting with mental illness were those on Medical (20.4%) and Medicare (31.5%), whereas only 12.4% of privately insured patients presented with mental illness. California has expanded its eligibility of Medi-Cal under federal law to cover as many people as possible.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Moulin A, Evans EJ, Xing G, Melnikow J | title = Substance Use, Homelessness, Mental Illness and Medicaid Coverage: A Set-up for High Emergency Department Utilization | journal = The Western Journal of Emergency Medicine | volume = 19 | issue = 6 | pages = 902–906 | date = November 2018 | pmid = 30429919 | pmc = 6225935 | doi = 10.5811/westjem.2018.9.38954 }}</ref> Inequalities in health are also determined by these socioeconomic and cultural factors.<ref name=WHO /> Health care is inequitably distributed globally, with pronounced inequality for the poor in low- and middle-income countries.<ref name=WHO /> One study demonstrated that doctors treat poor populations differently, showing that disadvantaged patients are less likely to receive the recommended diabetic treatments and are more likely to undergo hospitalization due to the complications of diabetes (Agency for Health Care Research and Quality, 2003).<ref name=WHO /> According to the [[World Health Organization|WHO]], healthcare systems can most improve health equality when institutions are organized to provide universal coverage, where everyone receives the same quality healthcare regardless of ability to pay, as well as a Primary Healthcare system rather than emergency center assistance.<ref name=WHO />
These structural problems result in worse healthcare and therefore worse health outcomes for impoverished populations. Health care costs can pose absolutely serious threats to impoverished populations, especially in countries without proper social provisions. According to US HHS, "In 2009, children 6–17 years of age were more likely to be uninsured than younger children, and children with a family income below 200% of the poverty level were more likely to be uninsured than children in higher-income families."<ref name=HHS /> In elderly populations, individuals below 400% of the poverty line were between 3 and 5 times more likely to lack insurance.<ref name=HHS /> Children below 200% of the poverty line were also less likely to have insurance than wealthier families.<ref name=HHS /> Also, in 2009 in the US, 20% of adults (ages 18–64) below 200% of the poverty line did not receive their necessary drugs because of cost, compared to only 4% of those above 400% of the poverty line.<ref name=HHS /> Increasing healthcare costs (including higher premiums) imposed a burden on consumers.<ref>{{Cite journal| vauthors = Mehta N, Ni J, Srinivasan K, Sun B |date=May 2017|title=A Dynamic Model of Health Insurance Choices and Healthcare Consumption Decisions|journal=Marketing Science|language=en|volume=36|issue=3|pages=338–360|doi=10.1287/mksc.2016.1021|issn=0732-2399 }}</ref> In 2010, President Obama introduced the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), expanding health care to many that lacked coverage. The U.S. had the highest rate of uninsured people, and the highest health care costs, of all industrialized nations at the time. The ACA helped 20 million Americans get coverage and decreased the rates of uninsured from 16% in 2010 to 8.6% in 2016. The ACA brought coverage to people who had had downgrades in Employee Insurance programs, by providing a health insurance marketplace, giving them access to private insurance plans along with income-based government subsidies.<ref>{{Cite journal| vauthors = Joseph TD, Marrow HB |date=2017-09-10|title=Health care, immigrants, and minorities: lessons from the affordable care act in the U.S. |journal=Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies|language=en|volume=43|issue=12|pages=1965–1984|doi=10.1080/1369183X.2017.1323446 |doi-access=free}}</ref> This can be seen in other nations, where in Asia, payments for healthcare pushed almost 3% of the population of 11 countries below 1 US$ per day.<ref name=WHO /> However, under the current U.S. administration, there have been shifts in how federal funding is allocated to social service programs. Although, initiatives like the National Prevention Council have been established to address prevention, there have also been some drawbacks. Because of this political shift, entities that address the social determinants of health in poverty, like social service programs, are threatened under these new policies. These policies reallocate funding away from public social service programs, causing resources that promote prevention and public health to be limited.<ref name=":0" /> The problem most present with state provisioned resources like public social service programs that aim to alleviate health disparities are the ever changing political spheres that either propel or block communities from access to effective health care resources and interventions. Despite the strength of political influences, it has been shown that, globally, shifting attention to addressing social needs like healthcare access has dramatically affected the health of impoverished communities.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Health and Nutrition of Children: Equity and Social Determinants Equity, Social Determinants and Public Health Programmes.|last=Blas|first=Erik|publisher=World Health Organization|year=2010|pages=49–75}}</ref>
===Societal psychological influences=== In impoverished communities, different [[social norms]] and stressors exist than in other populations, which can greatly affect health outcomes in disadvantaged populations.<ref name=HHS /> According to the National Institutes of Health, "low socioeconomic status may result in poor physical and/or mental health ... through various psychosocial mechanisms such as poor or "risky" health-related behaviors, social exclusion, prolonged and/ or heightened stress, loss of sense of control, and low self-esteem as well as through differential access to proper nutrition and to health and social services (National Institutes of Health 1998)."<ref name=HHS /> These stressors can cause physiological alterations including increased cortisol, changed blood-pressure, and reduced immunity which increases their risks for poor health.<ref name=HHS />
===Structural violence=== Underlying social structures that propagate and perpetuate poverty and suffering- [[structural violence]]- majorly determine health outcomes of impoverished populations. Poor and unequal living conditions result from deeper structural conditions, including "poor social policies and programs, unfair economic arrangements, and bad politics,"<ref name=WHO /> that determine the way societies are organized. The structure of the global system causes inequality and systematically higher death rates, which is caused by inequity in distribution of opportunities and resources, which is termed [[structural violence]].<ref name=dia>{{cite journal | last = Alcock | first = Norman | name-list-style = vanc | title = Structural Violence at the World Level: diachronic findings | journal = Journal of Peace Research | volume = XIV | issue = 3 | year = 1979 | pages = 255–262 | doi = 10.1177/002234337901600305 | s2cid = 108496866 }}</ref>
====Definition====
[[Structural violence]] is a term devised by [[Johan Galtung]] and [[liberation theologians]] during the 1960s to describe economic, political, legal, religious, and cultural social structures that harm and inhibit individuals, groups, and societies from reaching their full potential.<ref name=med /> Structural violence is structural because the causes of misery are "embedded in the political and economic organization of our social world; they are violent because they cause injury to people."<ref name="med"/> Structural violence is different from personal or behavioral violence because it exclusively refers to preventable harm done to people by no one clear individual, but arises from unequal distribution of power and resources, pre-built into social structure.<ref name=wei /> Structural violence broadly includes all kinds of violations of human dignity: absolute and relative poverty, social inequalities like gender inequality and racism, and outright displays of human rights violations.<ref name=path /> The idea of structural violence is as old as the study of [[Social conflict|conflict]] and [[violence]],<ref name=wei /> and so it can also be understood as related to [[social injustice]] and [[oppression]].<ref name=med />
====Effects====
Structural violence is often embedded in longstanding social structures, ubiquitous throughout the globe, that are regularized by persistent institutions and regular experience with them.<ref name=med /> These social structures seem so normal in our understanding of the world that they are almost invisible, but inequality in resource access, [[political power]], [[education]], [[healthcare]], and legal standing are all possible perpetrators of structural violence.<ref name=med /> Non citizens do not have access to medical insurance and healthcare and must seek care in clinics and outpatient departments.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ku L, Matani S | title = Left out: immigrants' access to health care and insurance | journal = Health Affairs | volume = 20 | issue = 1 | pages = 247–56 | date = January 2001 | pmid = 11194848 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.20.1.247 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Structural violence occurs "whenever persons are harmed, maimed, or killed by poverty and unjust social, political, and economic institutions, systems, or structures"<ref name=emp /> Structural violence can contribute to worse health outcomes through either harming or killing victims, just like armed violence can have these effects.<ref name=emp /> This type of unintended harm perpetuated by structural violence progressively promotes misery and [[hunger]] that eventually results in death, among other effects.<ref name=wei>{{cite book | first = Kathleen | last = Weigert |editor-last1=Fink | editor-first1=George | name-list-style = vanc |title=Stress of war, conflict and disaster| pages = 2004–2011 |date=2010|publisher=Elsevier/Academic Press|location=Amsterdam|isbn=978-0-12-381382-4 | doi = 10.1016/B978-012373985-8.00169-0 | chapter = Structural Violence }}</ref> Ehrlich and Ehrlich reported in 1970 that between 10 and 20 million of the 60 million annual deaths across the globe result from starvation and malnutrition.<ref name=emp /> Their report also estimated that structural violence was responsible for the end of one billion lives between 1948 and 1967 in the third world.<ref name=emp>{{cite journal | title = An Empirical Table of Structural Violence | first1 = Gernot | last1 = Köhler | first2 = Norman | last2 = Alcock | name-list-style = vanc | journal = Journal of Peace Research | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | year = 1976 | pages = 343–356 | jstor = 422498 | doi = 10.1177/002234337601300405 | s2cid = 108587221 }}</ref>
====Structural violence connection to health==== Inequality in daily living conditions stem from unseen social structures and practices.<ref name=WHO /> This systematic inequality is produced by social norms, policies, and practices that promote the unfair distribution of power, wealth, and other social resources,<ref name=WHO /> such as healthcare. "The poor health of the poor, the social gradient in health within countries, and the marked health inequities between countries are caused by the unequal distribution of power, [[income]], [[good (economics)|good]]s, and [[Public services|services]], globally and nationally."<ref name=WHO /> First, structural violence is often a major determinant of the distribution and outcome of disease.<ref name=med /> It has been known for decades that epidemic disease is caused by structural forces.<ref name=med /> [[Structural violence]] can affect disease progression, such as in [[HIV]], where harmful social structures profoundly affect [[diagnosis]], [[Staging (pathology)|staging]], and [[Therapy|treatment]] of HIV and associated illnesses.<ref name=med /> The determinants of disease and their outcome are set by the social factors, usually rampant with structural violence, that determine risk to be infected with the disease.<ref name=med /> Understanding how structural violence is embodied at the community, individual, and microbial levels is vital to understanding the dynamics of disease.<ref name=med /> The consequences of structural violence is post pronounced in the world's poorest countries and greatly affects the provision of clinical services in these countries.<ref name=med /> Elements of structural violence such as "social upheaval, poverty, and [[gender inequality]] decrease the effectiveness of distal services and of [[preventive medicine|prevention]] efforts" presents barriers to medical care in countries like Rwanda and Haiti<ref name=med /> Due to structural violence, there exists a growing outcome gap where some countries have access to interventions and treatment, and countries in poverty who are neglected. With the power of improved distal interventions, the only way to close this outcome gap between countries who do and do not have access to effective treatment, lies on proximal interventions to reduce the factors contributing to health problems that arise from structural violence.<ref name=med /><ref name=structural>{{cite journal | vauthors = Farmer P | title = The major infectious diseases in the world—to treat or not to treat? | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 345 | issue = 3 | pages = 208–10 | date = July 2001 | pmid = 11463018 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM200107193450310 }}</ref>
